014package org.jdbi.v3.core.array;
015
016import java.lang.reflect.Type;
017import java.sql.Types;
018import java.util.Collection;
019import java.util.Optional;
020import java.util.function.Function;
021
022import org.jdbi.v3.core.argument.Argument;
023import org.jdbi.v3.core.argument.ArgumentFactory;
024import org.jdbi.v3.core.argument.NullArgument;
025import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.ConfigRegistry;
026import org.jdbi.v3.core.internal.IterableLike;
027
028/**
029 * Bind a Java array or {@link Collection} to a SQL array using the
030 * {@link SqlArrayTypeFactory} for the given type information.  Note
031 * that due to type erasure, binding {@code Collection} arguments with
032 * {@link org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.SqlStatement#bind(int, Object)} may
033 * fail to determine the array component type.  Provide explicit information with
034 * {@link org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.SqlStatement#bindByType(int, Object, org.jdbi.v3.core.generic.GenericType)}.
035 *
036 * This factory is registered by default.
037 * @see SqlArrayType
038 * @see SqlArrayTypes
039 * @see org.jdbi.v3.core.config.Configurable#registerArrayType(SqlArrayType)
040 */
041public class SqlArrayArgumentFactory implements ArgumentFactory.Preparable {
042    @Override
043    public Optional<Function<Object, Argument>> prepare(Type type, ConfigRegistry config) {
044        return IterableLike.elementTypeOf(type)
045            .flatMap(config.get(SqlArrayTypes.class)::findFor)
046            .map(arrayType -> value -> arrayArgument(value, arrayType));
047    }
048
049    private Argument arrayArgument(Object value, SqlArrayType<?> arrayType) {
050        if (value == null) {
051            return new NullArgument(Types.ARRAY);
052        } else {
053            return new SqlArrayArgument<>(arrayType, value);
054        }
055    }
056}
